fm.atl: Density of states reflects diameter in nanotubes

aug.aff: Code 6179, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington , DC 20375, USA e-mail: white@alchemy.nrl.navy.mil

fp.p: Dresselhaus asked recently why scanning tunnelling microscopy and spectroscopy experiments, find a similar number of peaks, in the density of states near the Fermi level, for a range of semiconducting single-wall carbon nanotubes with roughly the same diameters. After all, semiconducting achiral zigzag single-wall nanotubes can have translational unit cells more than an order of magnitude smaller than those of chiral semiconducting single-wall nanotubes with a similar diameter, so they might be expected to have fewer but sharper peaks in their density of states. We show that all semiconducting single-wall nanotubes with similar diameters should have a similar density of states near the Fermi level, independent of translational unit cell size or chiral angle.

bdy.p: A single-wall nanotube (SWNT) can be constructed by rolling up a single sheet of graphite (graphene) along one of its two-dimensional lattice vectors R = n1R1+n2R 2 to form an (n1, n2) nanotube with diameter D = |R|/π. To a first approximation, the allowed electron states of the SWNT are the graphene bands satisfying the periodic boundary conditions k·R = 2πm, with m being an integer.

Graphically, these allowed kvalues lie along the parallel lines in Fig. 1a, which are perpendicular to R with an interline spacing of 2/D. The Fermi level, εF, is given by states at the corner points of the hexagonal Brillouin zone in Fig. 1a. So, neglecting the effects of curvature, nanotubes are either metallic or semiconducting depending on whether or not kF·R = 2πm, where kF = 4π( R1−R2)/9d2 and d is the carbon-carbon bond distance.

The two-dimensional dispersion relation of the occupied states of graphene is given to lowest order in d|k−kF| by ε_(k) = − |Vppπ|d|k−kF|, where Vppπis the nearest-neighbour ppπ interaction. Hence, near εF, ε_(k) is radially symmetric about the point kF located by k F and decreases with increasing |k−k F|.

For semiconducting SWNTs, the point of closest approach to k Fin any allowed line therefore yields to good approximation a local maximum in the one-dimensional band structure as long as d|k− kF| ≪ 1, leading to a van Hove singularity and a divergence in the occupied density of states (DOS) near εF. These special points also yield peaks in the unoccupied DOS because the dispersion relation for the unoccupied states is given by ε+( k) = −ε_(k). The special point on the line closest to kF (labelled as kAin Fig. 1b) also yields the SWNT band gap,. This point is separated from kF by a distance |k A−kF| = , one-third the interline spacing — a result easily confirmed by projecting kA−kF along R. So kAgenerates peaks in the DOS near ε ±(kA) = ±|Vppπ| d/D and a band gap near 2|Vppπ|d/ D when ≪ 1.

Incrementing by the interline spacing, 2/D, the next two special points yield peaks in the DOS near ε±(k B) = 2ε±(kA) = ±2| Vppπ|d/D when ≪ 1, and peaks near ε±(k C) = 4ε±(kA) = ±4 Vppπd/D when ≪ 1. Changing chirality at a given SWNT diameter effectively rotates the lines of allowed states around kF without changing the distances between the points along the lines and kF. Therefore the DOS of two semiconducting SWNTs with differing chiral angles but similar diameters are similar in the vicinity of εF because ε±(k) is radially symmetric about k F. A parallel analysis shows that all metallic SWNTs with similar diameters have similar DOS near εF within the graphene sheet model but with peaks close to ±3|Vppπ|d/D when ≪1.

All of these predictions are consistent with the numerical results shown in Fig. 1c. Because the semiconducting and metallic SWNTs studied experimentally all have d/D≈0.1 and V ppπ≈2.7 eV, these predictions explain the observed peak spacing in the SWNT DOS,, further confirming the band structure theory of these nanowires.

Circle at bottom right encloses region of states near εF. b, Expanded depiction of allowed states near εF, with dotted line parallel to R, kF corner of hexagon with energy ε F, and kA, kB and kC special points of closest approach to kF of three nearest allowed-state lines in reciprocal space. c, DOS per carbon, ρ(E), as a function of energy in units of α = |V ppπ|d/D computed using the full graphene dispersion relation ε±(k) = ±|Vppπ|{3+2cos( k·R1)+2cos(k·R2)+2cos[ k·(R1−R2)]}1/2 for six different SWNTs with similar diameters, D, for a range of chiral angles, &phis;, and number of atoms in the translation unit cell, NT. The average D for these six tubes is &Dmacr; = 1.33 nm for d = 0.142 nm with all D varying less than 3% from &Dmacr;.Also, α = 0.29 eV for Vppπ = −2.7 eV and D = &Dmacr;. All DOS are broadened by a lorentzian of width 0.01α. Shown are the DOS for the (17,0) [solid line; D = 1.33 nm, &phis; = 0°, NT = 68], (13,6) [dashed line; D = 1.32 nm, &phis; = 18°, NT = 1,132] and (11,9) [dotted line; D = 1.36 nm, &phis; = 27°, NT = 1,204] semiconducting SWNTs. Vertical lines A, B and C (corresponding to kA, kB, and kC in Fig. 1b) are peak positions in the occupied semiconducting DOS predicted using ε_(k) = − 3/2 |Vppπ|d|k - kF| approximately valid for |ε_−εF| ≪ 3/2| Vppπ|. Also shown are the DOS for the (10,10) [solid line; D = 1.36 nm, &phis; = 30°, NT = 40], (14,5) [dashed line; D = 1.34 nm, &phis; = 15°, NT = 1,164] and (16,1) [dotted line; D = 1.29 nm &phis; = 3°, NT = 1,092] metallic SWNTs offset upward by 0.03. Vertical line A′ is the first peak position in the occupied metallic DOS predicted from the approximate theory. Curvature introduces a small gap at εF in the non-armchair metallic tubes which is probably smeared out in the experimental results,.
